awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: A Half Century of Changing Glacier Dynamics at Athabasca Glacier
awd_abstract_narration:
Meltwater reaching the base of a glacier behaves like a lubricant, resulting in fast downslope movement.  In hot years, studies have shown that glaciers move relatively slow, as meltwater infiltrating the glacier form large subglacial rivers, that deprive the basal surface of meltwater.  However, it is difficult to make long-term predictions of glacier behavior from existing, short datasets, because we know the way a glacier responds to meltwater reaching the bed can change. This research will develop a unique long-term dataset to investigate how the speed and pattern of water-mediated glacier motion changes as a glacier?s shape and plumbing system adjust to a changing climate. The work will allow better prediction of future glacier change and enhance understanding of how glaciers shape landscapes over geologic time. We will train undergraduate and graduate students in field and laboratory research practices, preparing them for careers in science. We will partner with a documentary filmmaker and Jasper National Park (Alberta, Canada), which hosts our field site, to develop educational materials that will show park visitors the importance of glaciers and scientific research to human society.

Understanding centennial scale changes in basal motion is essential for predicting how the world?s glaciers will respond to climate warming, with implications for sea level rise and downstream habitat quality and water resources.  The investigators will revisit Athabasca glacier to offer a detailed picture of how the glacier basal motion has evolved as the glacier has thinned and retreated since seminal glaciology research conducted there in the 1960s. We will collect borehole inclinometry and water pressure, glacier surface velocity, radar-based ice thickness, and hydrometeorological data, among other field-based and remotely sensed observations. We will use a numerical glacier flow model to interpret these data. Our focus will allow us to extend insight gained at Athabasca Glacier to the rest of the world?s warm-bedded glaciers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sliding at the beds of glaciers, also known as basal motion, comprises a large portion of ice speed on many of the world`s glaciers.Changes in basal motion could modulate how glaciers respond to climate warming. The processes driving basal motion in the present are poorly understood. Changes over multidecadal periods due to climatic and geometric change (e.g., changing ice thickness and surface slope) are even less well constrained. Over the course of our project, we digitized historical information on the distribution of glacier ice thickness and speed from the 1960s. We collected modern equivalent datasets using field-based geophysics, on-glacier GPS systems, and instruments installed down boreholes drilled to the glacier bed (Figure 1). These datasets provided a unique opportunity for our team to describe how basal motion has changed in response to climatic warming and glacier thinning over a multidecadal time period.

Modern ground-based geophysics and lidar flights combined with historical aerial images and digitized surveys show that Athabasca Glacier thinned 60 m and retreated 600 m on average between 1961 - 2020 (Figure 2). The glacier slowed by 45% but steepened slightly (~1 °) over this same period. To investigate how basal motion responded to these changes, we designed, built, and installed 80 instruments down 12 boreholes drilled to the glacier bed (maximum depth = 270 m; Figure 3 a-c). These instruments transmitted information about their orientation as well as water pressure below the glacier from July 2022 - September 2023 (Figure 3d). The rate at which these sensors tilt over time shows how much ice motion is attributable to deformation throughout the ice. When combined with GPS measurements of glacier surface velocity, these borehole measurements allow estimation of how much glacier speed is attributable to basal motion. Comparing the modern borehole data to historical measurements, we found that deformation throughout the ice column changed very little, and that declining basal motion explained 70-100% of the observed slowing of Athabasca Glacier (Figure 4).

We used numerical ice flow models to extrapolate these findings to other parts of the glacier and explore potential physical controls. A flow model constrained by historical and modern surface observations, geophysical data, and borehole velocity information confirmed that basal motion dominated the slowing of Athabasca Glacier and show that similar dynamics prevail throughout most of our study reach (Figure 5). This same model showed that a more-than-doubling (+127%) of the friction at the ice-bed interface drove the decline in basal motion. An analysis of the force driving subglacial water flow utilizing ice surface slope and ice thickness data showed that changes in glacier geometry (thinning & steepening) over 1961 - 2020 as well as increased meltwater discharge from climate warming are likely important factors in increasing basal friction because they promote the glacier`s ability to evacuate water and reduce subglacial water pressure.

We extended these findings using an idealized glacier model to investigate how changes in basal motion modulate a glacier`s response to climate warming in a general sense. This model showed that a glacier experiences a two-phased response to declining basal motion in the absence of climate change, with a kilometer-scale retreat lasting ~75 years, followed by even larger advance over several centuries. This dynamic results in a 54% difference in glacier retreat in response to an abrupt climate warming event depending on whether basal motion slows or accelerates by 50% coincident with this event (Figure 6). If basal motion slows, the glacier undergoes faster initial retreat but less change on a centennial timescale, with the opposite true for cases of increasing basal motion.

Taken together, these findings show that declining basal motion dominated the slowing of Athabasca Glacier, and that this dynamic can substantially alter how a glacier responds to climate warming. It is uncertain to what extent these same processes have taken place on other glaciers, but if these phenomena are widespread they suggest that observed retreat rates may be exacerbated by slowing basal motion, but that long-term glacier change may be somewhat overestimated in cases where basal friction and sliding at the ice-bed interface are held constant in time. These findings have implications for global sea level rise as well as downstream water resources and aquatic habitat.

These findings are discussed in greater depth in the published papers cited below, with at least two more manuscripts in preparation at the time of the project`s end date.

Armstrong, W. H., Polashenski, D., Truffer, M., Horne, G., Hanson, J. B., Hawley, R. L., et al. (2022). Declining basal motion dominates the long-term slowing of Athabasca Glacier, Canada. Journal of Geophysical Research: Earth Surface, 127, e2021JF006439. https://doi.org/10.1029/2021JF006439 

Polashenski, D., Truffer, M., & Armstrong, W. H. (2024). Reduced basal motion responsible for 50 years of declining ice velocities on Athabasca Glacier. Journal of Glaciology, 1–13. https://doi.org/10.1017/jog.2024.51
